title: "The Symbolism of Dante's Tree: Restitution and Regeneration"
first_phrase: This section of the text delves into the symbol of the Avenger and Restorer, representing the Universal Lord in Dante's De Monarchia. It talks about the destruction of two connected principles of decay and restoration, linked to Paraçu-Râma. The text makes references to other symbols found in the saga of the Great Khan, Prester John, Ogier of Denmark, Alexander, and the imperial saga. It further discusses the dual meaning of the Tree of Knowledge and the Tree of Empire and how they signify Empire justified based on the primordial tradition. The text states that Dante's vision of the blossoming tree follows his vision of the supernatural woman's uncovered face.
content: El árbol dantesco es ante todo el Arbre Sec, el Dürre Baum de la saga imperial: «planta despojada», «viuda coqueta» - y de él se dice que «quien roba aquélla (la planta) o la arranca con blasfemia ofende de hecho a Dios - que sólo para uso suyo la creó santa». Sobre el desarrollo de la visión de Dante que a ello sigue, y omitiendo los elementos que tienen una referencia histórica contingente (los símbolos de las distintas fases de la Iglesia y de sus relaciones con el Imperio), detengámonos para destacar lo que sigue: la visión del árbol que florece la tiene Dante inmediatamente después de haber tenido la del rostro descubierto de la «mujer sobrenatural», que él compara significativamente con «esplendor de viva luz eterna».
last_phrase: In conclusion, Dante's vision of the rejuvenated tree represents a return to a primordial state of existence and the promise of a new manifestation of the "Universal Lord". This transformation is accompanied by a regeneration of Dante's sense of self, opening the way for him to ascend to the celestial realm. The use of powerful symbolism throughout the vision reflects the deep metaphysical and Christian themes central to the Divine Comedy.
